10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-010-9934-0993410.1007/s10870-010-9934-0Original PaperSynthesis and Structure of a CdI2 Coordination Polymer with 1,1′-(1,4-Butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt)LiangYu1LiuMei2ZhangNing3WangQingli3NiuYunyin3eLiuXiucun3HouHongwei3College of Chemistry and Chemical EngineeringXinxiang University453000XinxiangPeople’s Republic of ChinaChemical and Biological DepartmentHenan Jiaozuo Teacher’s College454000JiaozuoPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.207374.50000000121893846Department of ChemistryZhengzhou University450052ZhengzhouPeople’s Republic of China+8637167767627+8637167767627niuyy@zzu.edu.cn2312201052011415617620111220102420071012201023122010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

In this article, solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n1, and the crystal structure has been determined (C17 H20 Cd I2 N6 O), Mr = 690.59 a = 10.032(2), b = 13.503(3), c = 16.706(3) Å, space group C2/c,Z = 4, and V = 2223.1(8) Å3. In 1 the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.

Graphical Abstract

Solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n, in which the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.

KeywordsCadmium iodideCoordination polymerBenzotriazolevolume-issue-count12issue-article-count30issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2011issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2011article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2010article-registration-date-month12article-registration-date-day11article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productNonStandardArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2010_Article_9934.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2011issue-online-date-month3issue-online-date-day31issue-print-date-year2011issue-print-date-month3issue-print-date-day30issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallographyjournal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

The rational design and construction of supramolecular polymeric networks with intriguing architectures and topologies [1–3] have enjoyed significant success due to the potential applications in catalyst, superconductor, magnetic, and optical materials, etc. [4–6]. The general of this type of molecular architectures rests on several factors, such as the metals, the ligands, the solvents, the reaction conditions. The performance of the ligands and the selecting of the metal centers are crucial in the construction of metal-containing supramolecular architectures. The most commonly employed organic-connecters 4,4′-bpy and pyrazine are rigid, linear, bridging heterocyclic ligands, which have been numerously reported to form a large range of infinite framework. Recently, flexible ligands have been employed in order to gain access to topologies not available from the logical combination of rigid building blocks. The simplest way to introduce flexibility into ligand design is by incorporation of alkyl chain spacer groups, for example, symmetrical ligands containing propylene spacer groups between 4-pyrids [7, 8], 8-quionlyloxy [9], 1-pyrazoly [10], 1-triazoly [11], 2-benzimidazoly [12] donor groups have been used for the construction of interesting new supramolecular architectures.

On the other hand, Cd(II)-connecting coordination polymers [5] have attracted considerable recent interest owing to its large radius, various coordination modes, and special physical properties. To date, researchers have reported a number of 1D, 2D or 3D Cd(II) complexes for example, the 2D sheet CdI2 adduct [CdI2(4,4′-bpy)]n, and [CdI2(DMSO)]n [13, 14], 2D double helix coordination polymers[CdI2(2,2′-bpeec)I2]n [5], and [CdI2(bpytm)]n [15].

Taking account of the above considerations, we have chosen a flexible ligand, 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt, ω = 4, Scheme 1) as organic-connecter for its versatile alkyl spacer conformations and gained a new 1D coordination polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n.

ExperimentalGeneral Information and Materials

1,1′-(1,4-Butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) was prepared using a method previously described in the literature [16, 17]. All other chemicals were of AR grade without further purification; all solvents were predried over activated molecular sieves and refluxed over the appropriate drying agents under argon. The IR spectrum was recorded on a Shimazu IR-435 spectrometer as KBr disk (4000–400 cm−1).

Synthesis of [CdI<sub>2</sub> (bbbt) (CH<sub>3</sub>OH)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub><bold>1</bold>

A mixture of bbbt (0.198 g, 1.0 mmol) and methanol (5 mL) was heated and stirred for 10 min in air until it dissolved totally. The solution was slowly added to a colorless solution of CdI2 (0.454 g, 1.0 mmol) in 5 mL methanol, and then maintained undisturbed at ambient temperature. After 3 days’ solvent evaporation, colorless crystal blocks were collected by filtration (yield ca. 30%). IR data (KBr, cm−1) 2926.95w(CH2), 2821.63w(CH3), 1649w, 1594w, 1493w, 1448 m(N=N), 1328w(N–C), 1275w,1213 s, 1161w, 1109w, 1019w, 1018 m, 943w, 799w, 775w, 748vs(disubstituted phenyl), 704w, 426w.

X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data for the title compound 1 was collected at 291(2) K using Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the SHELX program [18], and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. The solvent molecule methanol (CH3OH) was partly disordered. Crystal data was summarized in detail in Table 1, selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1 are put in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure of [CdI<sub>2</sub> (bbbt) (CH<sub>3</sub>O H)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub><bold>1</bold>

The local structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n is shown in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdI2 molecule and a half of bbbt ligand. The Cd2+ atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from bbbt ligands and two iodide atoms in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. The distortion is probably the result of the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms [19, 20]. In adduct 1, both Cd–I(1) and Cd–I(1)#1 are 2.7011(7) Å, To our knowledge, this value gives a pair of shortest Cd–I lengths among CdI2 adducts, but Cd–N(1)#1 and Cd(1)–N(1) bond lengths are 2.296(4) Å, which is similar to those of the related polymers [CdI2(L)]n [7, 21, 22]. Compared with other CdI2 adducts with zigzag chain, we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of the larger I–Cd–I angle, the shortest Cd–I length, and final wave-shaped assembly structure.

In this compound, we know that the flexible butanediyl spacer decreases the rigidity of the chain from the C(8)#2–C(8)–C(7) angle of 113.5(7)°, which is between those of 115.08° and 122.42° in its related polymer [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n [23]. So the N–Cd–N angles [105.6(2)°] are larger than those in the zigzag structures [83–98.0°] [7]. For the same reason, the two independent benzotriazole ring of bbbt ligands are twisted to meet the requirement of steric exclusion, and their dihedral angles are 55.82°. Besides the two benzotriazole rings of the bbbt ligand which adopts a gauche-anti-gauche conformation [23–25] are parallel with dihedral angle of 0.00°. Other bond parameters are the same as those in its free state. So we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of this wavy-shaped structure.

In the solid-state structure, these chains extend along the a- direction through CdI2 units bridged by the bbbt ligands. Larger bond angles of I–Cd–I [120.97(3)°] and smaller N–Cd–N angles [105.6(2)°] in the complex are consistent with the preference of Cd2+ for soft donor I−, so the distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry around Cd2+ is probably beneficial for the formation of a polymeric structure (Fig. 2). Comparing to the similar compound [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2]n [24] with one-dimensional concavo-convex chain and interchain π–π interactions, we can conclude that their difference mainly results from the size and the steric effect of the anions.

Supplementary Material

Crystallographic data for the structure reported in this article has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, CCDC No. 623948 for compound 1. The information may be obtained free of charge from the Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge, CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44-12235 -336033; e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk or http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Acknowledgements

This research was funded by the National Natural Science Foundation (Grant No. 20671083) and the Science Foundation for Distinguished Young Scholars of Henan Province (Grant No. 0612002800).

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

In this article, solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n1, and the crystal structure has been determined (C17 H20 Cd I2 N6 O), Mr = 690.59 a = 10.032(2), b = 13.503(3), c = 16.706(3) Å, space group C2/c,Z = 4, and V = 2223.1(8) Å3. In 1 the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.

elements.content: Solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n, in which the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.
elements.clean_text:
Graphical Abstract

Solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n, in which the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.

elements.content: The rational design and construction of supramolecular polymeric networks with intriguing architectures and topologies [1–3] have enjoyed significant success due to the potential applications in catalyst, superconductor, magnetic, and optical materials, etc. [4–6]. The general of this type of molecular architectures rests on several factors, such as the metals, the ligands, the solvents, the reaction conditions. The performance of the ligands and the selecting of the metal centers are crucial in the construction of metal-containing supramolecular architectures. The most commonly employed organic-connecters 4,4′-bpy and pyrazine are rigid, linear, bridging heterocyclic ligands, which have been numerously reported to form a large range of infinite framework. Recently, flexible ligands have been employed in order to gain access to topologies not available from the logical combination of rigid building blocks. The simplest way to introduce flexibility into ligand design is by incorporation of alkyl chain spacer groups, for example, symmetrical ligands containing propylene spacer groups between 4-pyrids [7, 8], 8-quionlyloxy [9], 1-pyrazoly [10], 1-triazoly [11], 2-benzimidazoly [12] donor groups have been used for the construction of interesting new supramolecular architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The rational design and construction of supramolecular polymeric networks with intriguing architectures and topologies [1-3] have enjoyed significant success due to the potential applications in catalyst, superconductor, magnetic, and optical materials, etc. [4-6]. The general of this type of molecular architectures rests on several factors, such as the metals, the ligands, the solvents, the reaction conditions. The performance of the ligands and the selecting of the metal centers are crucial in the construction of metal-containing supramolecular architectures. The most commonly employed organic-connecters 4,4'-bpy and pyrazine are rigid, linear, bridging heterocyclic ligands, which have been numerously reported to form a large range of infinite framework. Recently, flexible ligands have been employed in order to gain access to topologies not available from the logical combination of rigid building blocks. The simplest way to introduce flexibility into ligand design is by incorporation of alkyl chain spacer groups, for example, symmetrical ligands containing propylene spacer groups between 4-pyrids [7, 8], 8-quionlyloxy [9], 1-pyrazoly [10], 1-triazoly [11], 2-benzimidazoly [12] donor groups have been used for the construction of interesting new supramolecular architectures.

elements.content: On the other hand, Cd(II)-connecting coordination polymers [5] have attracted considerable recent interest owing to its large radius, various coordination modes, and special physical properties. To date, researchers have reported a number of 1D, 2D or 3D Cd(II) complexes for example, the 2D sheet CdI2 adduct [CdI2(4,4′-bpy)]n, and [CdI2(DMSO)]n [13, 14], 2D double helix coordination polymers[CdI2(2,2′-bpeec)I2]n [5], and [CdI2(bpytm)]n [15].
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, Cd(II)-connecting coordination polymers [5] have attracted considerable recent interest owing to its large radius, various coordination modes, and special physical properties. To date, researchers have reported a number of 1D, 2D or 3D Cd(II) complexes for example, the 2D sheet CdI2 adduct [CdI2(4,4'-bpy)]n, and [CdI2(DMSO)]n [13, 14], 2D double helix coordination polymers[CdI2(2,2'-bpeec)I2]n [5], and [CdI2(bpytm)]n [15].

elements.content: Taking account of the above considerations, we have chosen a flexible ligand, 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt, ω = 4, Scheme 1) as organic-connecter for its versatile alkyl spacer conformations and gained a new 1D coordination polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n.
elements.clean_text: Taking account of the above considerations, we have chosen a flexible ligand, 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt, ω = 4, Scheme 1) as organic-connecter for its versatile alkyl spacer conformations and gained a new 1D coordination polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n.

elements.content: 1,1′-(1,4-Butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) was prepared using a method previously described in the literature [16, 17]. All other chemicals were of AR grade without further purification; all solvents were predried over activated molecular sieves and refluxed over the appropriate drying agents under argon. The IR spectrum was recorded on a Shimazu IR-435 spectrometer as KBr disk (4000–400 cm−1).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General Information and Materials

1,1'-(1,4-Butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) was prepared using a method previously described in the literature [16, 17]. All other chemicals were of AR grade without further purification; all solvents were predried over activated molecular sieves and refluxed over the appropriate drying agents under argon. The IR spectrum was recorded on a Shimazu IR-435 spectrometer as KBr disk (4000-400 cm-1).

elements.content: A mixture of bbbt (0.198 g, 1.0 mmol) and methanol (5 mL) was heated and stirred for 10 min in air until it dissolved totally. The solution was slowly added to a colorless solution of CdI2 (0.454 g, 1.0 mmol) in 5 mL methanol, and then maintained undisturbed at ambient temperature. After 3 days’ solvent evaporation, colorless crystal blocks were collected by filtration (yield ca. 30%). IR data (KBr, cm−1) 2926.95w(CH2), 2821.63w(CH3), 1649w, 1594w, 1493w, 1448 m(N=N), 1328w(N–C), 1275w,1213 s, 1161w, 1109w, 1019w, 1018 m, 943w, 799w, 775w, 748vs(disubstituted phenyl), 704w, 426w.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n1

A mixture of bbbt (0.198 g, 1.0 mmol) and methanol (5 mL) was heated and stirred for 10 min in air until it dissolved totally. The solution was slowly added to a colorless solution of CdI2 (0.454 g, 1.0 mmol) in 5 mL methanol, and then maintained undisturbed at ambient temperature. After 3 days' solvent evaporation, colorless crystal blocks were collected by filtration (yield ca. 30%). IR data (KBr, cm-1) 2926.95w(CH2), 2821.63w(CH3), 1649w, 1594w, 1493w, 1448 m(N=N), 1328w(N-C), 1275w,1213 s, 1161w, 1109w, 1019w, 1018 m, 943w, 799w, 775w, 748vs(disubstituted phenyl), 704w, 426w.

elements.content: Crystallographic data for the title compound 1 was collected at 291(2) K using Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the SHELX program [18], and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. The solvent molecule methanol (CH3OH) was partly disordered. Crystal data was summarized in detail in Table 1, selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1 are put in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Crystallographic data for the title compound 1 was collected at 291(2) K using Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073Å) on a Rigaku RAXIS-IV image plate area detector. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors and for absorption by using empirical scan data. The structure was solved with the SHELX program [18], and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods based on F2, with anisotropic thermal parameters for the non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atoms were located theoretically and not refined. The solvent molecule methanol (CH3OH) was partly disordered. Crystal data was summarized in detail in Table 1, selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1 are put in Table 2.

Symmetry transformations used to generate equivalent atoms

#1 x,−y + 1/2, z #2 −x + 1,−y + 1,−z

The local structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n is shown in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdI2 molecule and a half of bbbt ligand. The Cd2+ atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from bbbt ligands and two iodide atoms in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. The distortion is probably the result of the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms [19, 20]. In adduct 1, both Cd–I(1) and Cd–I(1)#1 are 2.7011(7) Å, To our knowledge, this value gives a pair of shortest Cd–I lengths among CdI2 adducts, but Cd–N(1)#1 and Cd(1)–N(1) bond lengths are 2.296(4) Å, which is similar to those of the related polymers [CdI2(L)]n [7, 21, 22]. Compared with other CdI2 adducts with zigzag chain, we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of the larger I–Cd–I angle, the shortest Cd–I length, and final wave-shaped assembly structure.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3O H)]n1

The local structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n is shown in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdI2 molecule and a half of bbbt ligand. The Cd2+ atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from bbbt ligands and two iodide atoms in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. The distortion is probably the result of the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms [19, 20]. In adduct 1, both Cd-I(1) and Cd-I(1)#1 are 2.7011(7) Å, To our knowledge, this value gives a pair of shortest Cd-I lengths among CdI2 adducts, but Cd-N(1)#1 and Cd(1)-N(1) bond lengths are 2.296(4) Å, which is similar to those of the related polymers [CdI2(L)]n [7, 21, 22]. Compared with other CdI2 adducts with zigzag chain, we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of the larger I-Cd-I angle, the shortest Cd-I length, and final wave-shaped assembly structure.

elements.content: ORTEP drawing of the asymmetric unit of [(CdI2) (bbbt)(CH3OH)]n1 with displacement ellipsoids at the 30% probability level. Hydrogens are removed for clarity
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1ORTEP drawing of the asymmetric unit of [(CdI2) (bbbt)(CH3OH)]n1 with displacement ellipsoids at the 30% probability level. Hydrogens are removed for clarity

elements.content: In this compound, we know that the flexible butanediyl spacer decreases the rigidity of the chain from the C(8)#2–C(8)–C(7) angle of 113.5(7)°, which is between those of 115.08° and 122.42° in its related polymer [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n [23]. So the N–Cd–N angles [105.6(2)°] are larger than those in the zigzag structures [83–98.0°] [7]. For the same reason, the two independent benzotriazole ring of bbbt ligands are twisted to meet the requirement of steric exclusion, and their dihedral angles are 55.82°. Besides the two benzotriazole rings of the bbbt ligand which adopts a gauche-anti-gauche conformation [23–25] are parallel with dihedral angle of 0.00°. Other bond parameters are the same as those in its free state. So we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of this wavy-shaped structure.
elements.clean_text: In this compound, we know that the flexible butanediyl spacer decreases the rigidity of the chain from the C(8)#2-C(8)-C(7) angle of 113.5(7)°, which is between those of 115.08° and 122.42° in its related polymer [Cd(bbbt)2(NCS)2]n [23]. So the N-Cd-N angles [105.6(2)°] are larger than those in the zigzag structures [83-98.0°] [7]. For the same reason, the two independent benzotriazole ring of bbbt ligands are twisted to meet the requirement of steric exclusion, and their dihedral angles are 55.82°. Besides the two benzotriazole rings of the bbbt ligand which adopts a gauche-anti-gauche conformation [23-25] are parallel with dihedral angle of 0.00°. Other bond parameters are the same as those in its free state. So we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of this wavy-shaped structure.

elements.content: In the solid-state structure, these chains extend along the a- direction through CdI2 units bridged by the bbbt ligands. Larger bond angles of I–Cd–I [120.97(3)°] and smaller N–Cd–N angles [105.6(2)°] in the complex are consistent with the preference of Cd2+ for soft donor I−, so the distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry around Cd2+ is probably beneficial for the formation of a polymeric structure (Fig. 2). Comparing to the similar compound [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2]n [24] with one-dimensional concavo-convex chain and interchain π–π interactions, we can conclude that their difference mainly results from the size and the steric effect of the anions.
elements.clean_text: In the solid-state structure, these chains extend along the a- direction through CdI2 units bridged by the bbbt ligands. Larger bond angles of I-Cd-I [120.97(3)°] and smaller N-Cd-N angles [105.6(2)°] in the complex are consistent with the preference of Cd2+ for soft donor I-, so the distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry around Cd2+ is probably beneficial for the formation of a polymeric structure (Fig. 2). Comparing to the similar compound [Zn(bbbt)(NCS)2]n [24] with one-dimensional concavo-convex chain and interchain π-π interactions, we can conclude that their difference mainly results from the size and the steric effect of the anions.

Synthesis of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n1

The solution was slowly added to a colorless solution of CdI2 (0.454 g, 1.0 mmol) in 5 mL methanol, and then maintained undisturbed at ambient temperature. IR data (KBr, cm-1) 2926.95w(CH2), 2821.63w(CH3), 1649w, 1594w, 1493w, 1448 m(N=N), 1328w(N-C), 1275w,1213 s, 1161w, 1109w, 1019w, 1018 m, 943w, 799w, 775w, 748vs(disubstituted phenyl), 704w, 426w.

cln_elements.content:
In this article, solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n1, and the crystal structure has been determined (C17 H20 Cd I2 N6 O), Mr = 690.59 a = 10.032(2), b = 13.503(3), c = 16.706(3) Å, space group C2/c,Z = 4, and V = 2223.1(8) Å3. In 1 the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure of [CdI<sub>2</sub> (bbbt) (CH<sub>3</sub>O H)]<sub><italic>n</italic></sub><bold>1</bold>

The local structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n is shown in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdI2 molecule and a half of bbbt ligand. The Cd2+ atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from bbbt ligands and two iodide atoms in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. The distortion is probably the result of the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms [19, 20]. In adduct 1, both Cd–I(1) and Cd–I(1)#1 are 2.7011(7) Å, To our knowledge, this value gives a pair of shortest Cd–I lengths among CdI2 adducts, but Cd–N(1)#1 and Cd(1)–N(1) bond lengths are 2.296(4) Å, which is similar to those of the related polymers [CdI2(L)]n [7, 21, 22]. Compared with other CdI2 adducts with zigzag chain, we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of the larger I–Cd–I angle, the shortest Cd–I length, and final wave-shaped assembly structure.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

In this article, solution reaction of cadmium iodide with organic multifunctional ligand 1,1'-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole(bbbt) generated a 1D polymer [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n1, and the crystal structure has been determined (C17 H20 Cd I2 N6 O), Mr = 690.59 a = 10.032(2), b = 13.503(3), c = 16.706(3) Å, space group C2/c,Z = 4, and V = 2223.1(8) Å3. In 1 the tetrahedral coordination of Cd(II) and the conformation of bbbt ligand make it a wave-shaped structure.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3O H)]n1

The local structure of [CdI2 (bbbt) (CH3OH)]n is shown in Fig. 1. The asymmetric unit consists of a CdI2 molecule and a half of bbbt ligand. The Cd2+ atom is coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from bbbt ligands and two iodide atoms in a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. The distortion is probably the result of the strong preference of metal for soft donors such as iodine atoms with large atom size and weak preference for N atoms [19, 20]. In adduct 1, both Cd-I(1) and Cd-I(1)#1 are 2.7011(7) Å, To our knowledge, this value gives a pair of shortest Cd-I lengths among CdI2 adducts, but Cd-N(1)#1 and Cd(1)-N(1) bond lengths are 2.296(4) Å, which is similar to those of the related polymers [CdI2(L)]n [7, 21, 22]. Compared with other CdI2 adducts with zigzag chain, we can reason that the conformation of bbbt plays an important role in the formation of the larger I-Cd-I angle, the shortest Cd-I length, and final wave-shaped assembly structure.
